utterances: It's a little bit like going to a new place where you're not sure whether there would be water or power.
Do you think that you'll be able to survive there?
That's the question that this report poses.
For 314 species, we know that there's a great probability that they're going to be facing very different climate futures, and their outcomes are really unsure.
So let me just zero in if we can.
And you mention loons in Minnesota - this is the species the common loon.
And I think we have a little bit of tape to play, if people might, you know, even recognize this.
(SOUNDBITE OF COMMON LOON)
So describe this species for me if you can.
The New York Giants have pulled off one of the biggest upsets in NFL history.
They defeated the undefeated New England Patriots 17 to 14.
Jason Jagpout(ph) was celebrating in New York's Time Square.
It very well could result in unqualified people voting.
It could also result in people voting more than once.
And most importantly, because of the clog of paperwork of some of these registrations, it could deny election officials the time they need to get their registration lists in order.
And he said that might block legitimate voters from casting ballots.
He and Danforth say they'd like to work with the Obama campaign to monitor polls on Election Day for irregularities, but campaign officials say they'd prefer Republicans clean up their own act.
They say Republicans are the ones trying to prevent legitimate voters from going to the polls by scaring them.
They point to an incident last week in Greene County, Ohio, where a sheriff sought the records of 300 people who had registered and voted early because he said he was worried about possible fraud.
Democrats called it a fishing expedition directed at newly registered college students.
The sheriff later dropped his request.
Pam Fessler, NPR News, Washington.
Today we focus on your money, spending on candy and the movies.
The animated film ""Chicken Little,"" opens next Friday.
It features the voices of Zach Braff and Garry Marshall, and, for the Walt Disney Company, a great deal is riding on the back of this little chicken.
NPR's Kim Masters reports.
It's safe to say that Disney's version of ""Chicken Little"" is a new riff on old material.
This time, for instance, the protagonist gets updated advice on his credibility problem from his best pals: The Ugly Duckling and a very big pig called Runt of the Litter.
(Soundbite of ""Chicken Little"")
(As The Ugly Duckling) Runt, should Chicken Little have a good talk with his dad and clear the air or keep searching for Band-Aid solutions and never deal with the problem?
(As Runt of the Litter) Band-Aid solutions?
(As The Ugly Duckling) Runt!
(As Runt of the Litter) What?
I'm sorry.
I'm very bad at reading facial cues.
(As The Ugly Duckling) Ugh!
Chicken Little"" may be a small bird but the movie has become a big deal.
It's being seen as a test of Disney's once-vaunted animation prowess after several difficult years.
David Stainton, the head of Disney Animation, says ""Chicken Little,"" arguably the company's first homegrown computer-animated film, will be a turning point.
We've had some fallow years and I think that this is the first movie of, you know, a whole new period for us.
Traditional hand-drawn films like ""Brother Bear"" and ""Home on the Range"" didn't perform well.
Meanwhile, computer-generated animation took off and Disney was not in the game.

It made money on a string of hits produced by its then-partners at Pixar, including ""Finding Nemo"" and ""The Incredibles."" But Pixar has split from Disney, and, meanwhile, other rivals came onto the field of play.
DreamWorks made ""Shrek"" and ""Madagascar."" Fox produced ""Ice Age"" and ""Robots."" Jim Hill is a self-described Disney geek whose Web site tracks all things Disney.
He's seen parts of ""Chicken Little"" and thinks it's a nice little movie but not the blockbuster that Disney needs.
It's so clearly influenced by ""Shrek,"" and, likewise, the Pixar films.
It's, you know, just like now, you know, the leader is following everybody else's lead.
Entertainment industry analyst Harold Vogel has seen parts of the movie, too, and he thinks ""Chicken Little"" will be a hit.
I think the key to it is the cuteness factor of ""Chicken Little."" They have just made it very cute, and cute counts for a lot.

In fact, Vogel thinks ""Chicken Little"" will not just give Disney a morale boost and generate a lot of money, it will also give the company a bargaining chip as it attempts to reestablish its now ruptured relationship with Pixar.
...(Unintelligible) say that, `Well, gosh, look how we did all by ourselves.
We don't need Pixar quite as badly as everyone thought.'
Even if ""Chicken Little"" succeeds, Vogel believes Disney will still make a new deal with Pixar, rather than allow its former partner to link up with a competing studio.
Jim Hill agrees.
And he thinks Pixar can then force Disney to yield the most profitable release dates for Pixar's movies.
So to him the return of Pixar would be a mixed blessing.
He loves Pixar movies but he fears what will happen if the mighty Pixar returns to the Disney fold.
Disney Feature Animation is then going to have to be handicapped, and end up being, you know, the red-headed stepchild in its own house.
Disney Animation chief David Stainton says that's not so.
My mission and my mandate, you know, has been to reinvent Walt Disney Feature Animation which I feel like we are in the process of doing quite successfully.
So, you know, regardless of what happens with Pixar, that's going to continue to be my mission and I happily accept it.
Certainly Disney fans are hoping that whether the chicken is big or little, that mission will succeed.
Kim Masters, NPR news, Los Angeles.
This is MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Steve Inskeep.
A Senate committee has approved a plan to give new investigative powers to the FBI.
The provision would be part of the USA Patriot Act, which is being updated.
This provision would allow the FBI to obtain documents, including medical records, without a judge's approval.
Civil liberties groups will try to remove those powers before the bill becomes law.
NPR's Larry Abramson reports.
Public concern about the USA Patriot Act has brought a spotlight to the ordinarily secretive Senate Intelligence Committee.
The key reason is the panel's decision to grant the FBI a new tool.
It's called an administrative subpoena.
It would allow the FBI to get hold of documents, from medical records to credit card information, without any oversight by a judge.
Senator Pat Roberts, chair of the committee, said at a recent hearing that other agencies have long used this power.
Support for NPR comes from Orean and Armstrong Seeds and Seedlings, planting ideas and artichokes.
We bring the world to your plate.

And what that safety net does is, if parents are meeting the work eligibility requirements, you know, working the minimum hours required to collect cash payments from the welfare system, there's still an emergency payment that goes to their children or goes for supporting their children.
It's meant to avoid homelessness.
The governor's proposing removing those kinds of emergency cash grants under the idea that the parents will work if you take this cash away from them.
They're also taking away the cost of living adjustment for this year.
He's proposing to do that.
And he's also proposing taking away some payments that go to the children of illegal immigrants.

The governor's finance director has said - you quote him in your article saying, look, if we don't make these adjustments, we're going to lose federal money - hundreds of millions of dollars of federal money - because they require that the parents who get this work some certain minimum number of hours.
And in California they're not doing it.
Yes, that is true.
The governor's finance director did indeed say that.
There was a federal law passed recently to require sort of more participation in the work programs in welfare in the states.
California's fallen behind for a number of reasons.
One of the reasons our work requirement is so low though is because we're one of the few states that provides this, this safety net.
So there are a lot of families where, you know, these emergency grants for the children exist and then the parents aren't working and thus the work requirement participant rate goes down.
Now, the governor's department of finance says that California has to do this or the federal government is going to take cash assistance away from the state and hundreds of millions of dollars.
Other analysts have looked at this and said there's any number of ways that the state can meet the new federal requirements without removing these cash grants that are intended for the children.
I'll just note that you do report what these cash grants are as an example in your piece.
A single parent with two children might get, I think it's $534 a month in Los Angeles.
That's pretty hard to live on, a parent with two kids.
Yeah.
That is the amount that we're talking about here.
And you know, you add up the tens of thousands of families, it comes - it turns into quite a bit of money for the state, which is facing a five and a half billion dollar deficit.
Well, what about this proposal?
The governor's also suggesting to the legislature that there be new health insurance provided for families.
And poor kids would get their health coverage paid for.
How are the Democrats going to respond to both of these proposals?
Well, that's what's interesting.
The Democrats were taken a little bit by surprise by this welfare proposal, which the governor announced on a Sunday afternoon.
And he briefed the media before he even briefed them, apparently.

You know, it's unclear whether what the governor is doing here exactly - I mean, you know, healthcare has appealed to him more than welfare programs because as centrist, you know, the governor's all about the middle class.
And there's not a lot of sympathy, especially among Republicans, for some of these - some of these welfare programs.
Democrats have said they like the healthcare part.
They don't like the welfare part.
And they intend to resist it.

Part of what the governor is doing here, there's a political calculus, because his healthcare program has already put off a lot of the Republicans in the legislature whose support he'll need to pass any ambitious new spending program.

This welfare proposal essentially works as a way to maybe bring them back into the fold, show them he's still a tough fiscal conservative, despite his plans to increase healthcare dramatically, and still wants to cut other government programs.
Evan Halper, a reporter for the Los Angeles Times.
Evan, thank you.
Thank you very much.
This fall in a series called Living Large, NPR's exploring how life is changing in a country where one in three people is obese.
A place you can see that change is the marketplace.
Americans today spent $61 billion a year on everything from diet pills and exercise videos to meal plans, health club memberships and medical treatments.
Today, NPR's Carrie Kahn examines one more lucrative segment of the weight loss market: surgery.
